Yii Framework v2.0.0-dev Class Reference

Trait yii\db\ActiveQueryTrait

All Classes | Properties | Methods
Implemented byyii\db\ActiveQuery, yii\db\ActiveRelation, yii\redis\ActiveQuery, yii\redis\ActiveRelation
Available since version2.0
Source Code
ActiveQueryTrait implements the common methods and properties for active record query classes.

Public Properties

Hide inherited properties

PropertyTypeDescriptionDefined By
$modelClass string The name of the ActiveRecord class yii\db\ActiveQueryTrait
$with array A list of relations that this query should be performed with yii\db\ActiveQueryTrait
$asArray boolean Whether to return each record as an array yii\db\ActiveQueryTrait

Property Details

$modelClass property
string $modelClass = null

The name of the ActiveRecord class.

$with property
array $with = null

A list of relations that this query should be performed with

$asArray property
boolean $asArray = null

Whether to return each record as an array. If false (default), an object of $modelClass will be created to represent each record.

Method Details

__call() method
mixed __call( $name, $params )
$name string The method name to be called
$params array The parameters passed to the method
return mixed the method return result
throws yii\base\InvalidCallException

PHP magic method.

This method allows calling static method defined in $modelClass via this query object. It is mainly implemented for supporting the feature of scope.

asArray() method
static asArray( $value = true )
$value boolean Whether to return the query results in terms of arrays instead of Active Records.
return static the query object itself

Sets the asArray() property.

with() method
static with( )
return static the query object itself

Specifies the relations with which this query should be performed.

The parameters to this method can be either one or multiple strings, or a single array of relation names and the optional callbacks to customize the relations.

A relation name can refer to a relation defined in $modelClass or a sub-relation that stands for a relation of a related record. For example, orders.address means the address relation defined in the model class corresponding to the orders relation.

The followings are some usage examples:

// find customers together with their orders and country
Customer::find()->with('orders', 'country')->all();
// find customers together with their orders and the orders' shipping address
Customer::find()->with('orders.address')->all();
// find customers together with their country and orders of status 1
Customer::find()->with([
    'orders' => function($query) {
        $query->andWhere('status = 1');
    },
    'country',
])->all();

You can call with() multiple times. Each call will add relations to the existing ones. For example, the following two statements are equivalent:

Customer::find()->with('orders', 'country')->all();
Customer::find()->with('orders')->with('country')->all();

findWith() method
void findWith( $with, &$models )
$with array A list of relations that this query should be performed with. Please refer to with() for details about specifying this parameter.
$models array The primary models (can be either AR instances or arrays)

Finds records corresponding to one or multiple relations and populates them into the primary models.
